titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI: Monday. The first Session of the fifteenth Congress commenced this day; a Quorum of both Houses was formed, and Mr Clay was chosen Speaker of the House of Representatives. When I called at the President’s with my papers I found a Mr Lomax with him— Mr G. Hay junr. afterwards came in. The President had removed into his cabinet, which is new papered. He appointed Wednesday at One O’Clock for an Audience to Don Luis de Onis, the Spanish Minister to deliver a Letter from the king of Spain— I found Mr Onis himself at the Office of the Department, and had a Conference with him of two hours. His propositions for a Treaty were the same as those made by Mr Pizarro to Mr Erving, which I told him were so inadmissible that it would be useless to enter upon the discussion of them— He nevertheless referred to many documents to prove that Louisiana never extended westward of the Mississippi; and enlarged upon the interest of the United States and Spain to harmonize together, with other Powers against the commercial domination of Great Britain— Onis had also an inofficial proposal to make to me; which was that I inofficially should authorize any Agent of the United States going to Buenos Ayres, to ransom for 15 per Cent or more two ships belonging to the Spanish Philippine Company taken by a privateer under the Buenos Ayres flag, but fitted out from Baltimore, and manned by Citizens of the United States— This I also declined— I was employed all the Evening, in examining papers referred by the House of Representatives to the Secretary of State at the last Session of Congress; and I made the draft of a Report on the Petition of Winslow and Henry Lewis.

2. VI:Mr Jonathan Robinson formerly a member of the Senate of the United States from Vermont, at the time when I was a member of the same body, called at my house this Morning. He is now a Commissioner from that State to support certain claims which they have against the United States— He also recommended a Newspaper Printer for printing the Laws in the State of Vermont— Genl: S. Smith was also here, and spoke of South-American affairs; and said if a Minister should be sent to Prussia it would be quite agreeable to his son John to receive the appointment. I told him it would depend upon Congress whether a Minister should be sent to Prussia; and that if there should, his Son would have among others a family rival in Mr Hughes— He said he had been aware of that; but he thought the Government had done enough for Hughes— At the Office, Mr Nourse the Register of the Treasury came with Kusick and Longboard, two Tuscorora Indians, who brought me a Letter of recommendation from Mr M’Leod, Secretary to a Missionary Society at New-York. They are going to North Carolina, upon some claim of Lands in that State, which formerly belonged to their Tribe, and which they complain have been taken from them— They also have a claim to Congress, for the rebuilding of a Church of theirs which during the late War was destroyed by the British Indians— They are to call upon me again— Mr Ten Cate, the Chargé d’Affaires from the Netherlands paid me his Official visit— Mr J. T. Austin Agent to the Commission, under the fourth Article of the Treaty of Ghent came, and brought all the Books and Records belonging to the Commission; Mr Austin does not consider his Commission as Agent yet terminated; and proposes to be further employed to take possession of the islands to be restored to the United States— A Mr Hays came with recommendations for an Appointment as judge in theTerritory— I received applications from the British & French Ministers for Interviews; both of which I appointed for to-morrow— It was five O’Clock before I left the Office, and just as I reached my own door, I met a man & woman in a Chaise from Alexandria, with a
petition to the President for a pardon for a man convicted of petty Larceny at Alexandria. They had been to the President’s and were told that they must come to me, to have the pardon made out; and the man insisted that it must be done this Evening. I told him that was impossible as the pardon must be made out at the office, which was shut up, and directed them to call there to-morrow Morning— Just after dinner there came an Express from the Post-Master at Baltimore, with a Letter from Messrs: Rodney, Graham & Bland, dated at Norfolk 30. Novr. to say that Captain Sinclair of the frigate Congress in which they are to sail, had not received his orders from the Navy Department. The Express had also a packet for Mr Crowninshield the Secretary of the Navy, and a Letter to Commodore Porter— Also an order upon the accountant of the State Department from J. S. Skinner, Post Master at Baltimore, to pay the Express twenty Dollars. I certified the order upon it, and sent the man to Mr Young’s for payment— The Express was unnecessary.

3. VI:Mr Holmes late Commissioner, under the fourth Article of the Treaty of Ghent, and Mr Austin the Agent were at my house this Morning— I called at the Office; then at the Spanish Minister’s where I left Cards; and then proceeded to the President’s, where the Spanish Minister, arrived immediately after me— I presented him to the President to whom he delivered a Letter from the King of Spain addressed to the United States of America. His Audience was short, and when he went away I returned to the President with my budget of papers upon which I took his directions— At the Office I had interviews with Mr Bagot, at two and with Hyde de Neuville at three O’Clock— Bagot came, about the fisheries, and the British Officers imprisoned at Philadelphia. I spoke to him also about Moose Island, concerning which he said he would write— Hyde de Neuville urged again for something to be done about Lakanal, and his papers; but admitted that all the projects which had alarmed him were at an end. He also wished to know how he was to pay his respects to the President; I told him by leaving a Card at his house. He said he should not dare to leave a Card at the President’s, and they had never left Cards at Mr Madison’s. The Ladies too were embarrassed how to proceed with regard to Mrs Monroe; and he wished me to speak of it, to the President again. He said he should also write to me, about Beaumarchais’s affair and two others, upon which he had written before— Mr Joseph Forrest came to the Office, upon a Petition of his to Congress, referred, by a Resolution of the House of Representatives to the Department of State. It was past five O’Clock when I left the Office— This day we had the first Snow, and this Evening it cleared off cold. J. C. Calhoun, Secy: of War arrived.

4. VI:30. The cold weather has again returned. Fahrenheit this morning at 18. I was at the President’s with my papers, and three times interrupted—the last time by Mr Robertson of Louisiana; whom I left with the President. Mr Ten Cate the Chargé d’Affaires from the Netherlands came by appointment at two O’Clock— He told me that the discriminating duties of 3 per Cent additional upon foreign Tonnage at Surinam had been repealed, and referred to a former proposal of his Government, that an equalization of duties should be declared by proclamation of the President without waiting for the Conclusion of a Treaty, but under the Act of Congress of 3. March 1815; but which this Government had declined— He also asked me to fix a time, when he could come and introduce to me, a Mr. Furstenwerter, a nephew of Baron von Gagern, the Minister of the Netherlands, at the Diet of Frankfort. He said this young man came with a private Mission, which might in the end become a public one, for the establishment of a German Colony, in some of the new settlements of the United States— I agreed to receive them to-morrow at two. Mr Austin came again and I informed him of the President’s determination with regard to the Salary of the Agents to the Commissions under the Treaty of Ghent, and of his opinion that the agency terminated with the Commission. But that perhaps there may be occasion to send a special Messenger to England, with Instructions to make arrangements for carrying the decision of the Commissioners under the fourth Article into effect. I am by the President’s directions to see Mr Bagot again upon the subject to-morrow— Coll. Lane was at the Office, and requested me as the President had informed me that he would, to write to Mr
Charles Bulfinch of Boston offering him the appointment of Architect to the Public Buildings here, in the place of H. Latrobe, resigned. I had yesterday received a Letter from Bulfinch asking for the appointment— This day I had one from J. Trumbull at New-York, recommending an Englishman named Hatfield. I answered Trumbull that it was too late— Mr Hopkinson of Philadelphia, and Mr R. Walsh spent the Evening with me—

5. VI: Morning occupied in drafting a Report to the House of Representatives upon a Memorial of certain Inhabitants of Detroit in the Michigan Territory, and Letters to Bagot, and Hyde de Neuville. A persons named Alexander Coffin from New-York, came to my house, and brought me a letter from the Secretary of the Navy, Mr Crowninshield— Coffin kept me at least an hour and a half stating to me the history of a valuable vessel and cargo, of which he was Captain and part owner taken and condemned by the British Admiralty Courts in 1804. and for which he wishes this Government now, to support him in claiming indemnity from the British Government. There is an excess of absurdity, in many of the persons who have claims, that no Patience can tolerate or withstand— I was at the President’s with my papers— and at his desire left with him. My draft of a Report upon the Michigan Memorial. At the Office I had Mr: Bagot, Mr Ten Cate with Baron Fürstenwerder, and the two Indians Kusick and Longboard. Bagot came at my request. The President having desired me to see him again, and inform him that I should write to enquire of him whether he, or any of the British Governors on this Continent were authorized to carry into execution the decision of the Commissioners on the 4th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent, by restoring to the United States, possession of Moose, Dudley and Frederick Islands— Bagot said that he had no such power. Sir John Sherbrook the Governor General of Canada, or Lord Dalhousie, Governor of Nova-Scotia might have it—if either, probably the former. He doubted whether either had it; but would write immediately to ascertain. He had written already to his Government upon the subject last Evening— Fürstenwerder is a young man sent by his uncle the Baron de Gagern, Minister from the king of the Netherlands at the Germanic diet at Frankfort, to collect information of all kinds concerning the German emigrants to this Country— The Indians brought the papers relating to their Lands in North-Carolina— Mr Nourse and Mr E. B. Caldwell assist them with their advice and by writing but the members from North-Carolina, are unwilling to act, and my hands and tongue are tied by my situation. I told them I would see Mr Nourse concerning their Affairs— I wrote yesterday to Alexander Anderson, the son of the Comptroller offering him the vacant Clerk’s Office in the Department of State, with a Salary of 1350 dollars a year, and this day received his answer declining it—

6. VI:30. As I was going out this Morning, Mr Holmes and Mr Tallmadge—members of the House of Representatives called at my house, and kept me nearly an hour in Conversation— I called at Mr Anderson the Comptroller’s Office, and found Pleasonton with him. There came in several other persons, but upon the subject on which I called I could not wait for another time to speak to him— I told him that I had offered the vacant Clerkship in my Office to his son Alexander, who had declined it; at which I had been somewhat surprized; as he the father had applied to me for it— He said he thought it was best to be candid with me on the subject—it was because I had not offered him the Clerkship with 1500 dollars Salary instead of the one with 1350 dollars. Young Anderson is about 22 years of age, and has a place in his father’s Office of 12 or 1300 dollars. At Quincy I received a Letter from his father, telling me he had a friend to recommend to me, for Chief Clerk in my Office— This Son Alexander was that friend. The application from Mr Bailey had been previous to Anderson’s, and when I arrived here on comparing the just claims of all the persons, presented to me as Candidates, I confirmed Mr Daniel Brent in the Office of Chief Clerk. which he had ever since the Resignation of Mr Graham, on the fourth of March last. He was strongly recommended by Mr Monroe and Mr Rush, had many years experience of the business of the Office, was a man of forty years of age, or upwards and of the most respectable character. I could on no consideration remove such a man to make way for any other— Then came the 1500 dollar Clerkship— Anderson himself told me that the President wished that might be offered to his brother Joseph— I therefore offered it to him— The next, the 1350 dollar office, Anderson at first said would not suit his son; but William S. Smith had got a temporary Office of 1000 dollars a year Salary, under Anderson; which Clerkship Anderson wanted to suppress, to encrease with it the Salary of his Son, and so he proposed to me to give W. S. Smith my 1350 dollar Clerkship, so that he Anderson might get rid of him— I told him I should appoint no Relation of my own to any Office under me— The next step was a communication from Anderson to me through Mr Crawford; that W. S. Smith should
be retained in the Office under Anderson if I would give Anderson’s son the 1350 dollar Clerkship, in the Department, which in the particular circumstances of the case he would consent to accept— I told Crawford that I could make no such bargain, and would neither directly nor indirectly contribute to place any relation of mine in any office— Crawford then intimated that W. S. Smith must consequently be dismissed from the place under Anderson, upon which I observed that I had nothing to say. Smith was accordingly dismissed, and W. Lee gave him a place of the same Salary in his Office, without any knowledge of mine. Smith and his wife, and all the family were up in arms against me about it, but I thought my Resolution right and adhered to it— I offered the 1350 dollar Clerkship to Mr Bailey, who had been several years a tutor at Providence College, was a member of the Legislature of Massachusetts, and had a multitude of the strongest Recommendations. He accepted it, though his application too had been for the Office of Chief Clerk, and he was something reluctant at taking a fourth place, instead— When Mr Monroe declined the 1500 dollar place, I assigned it of course to Mr Bailey— Anderson instantly got wind that Monroe had declined, and spoke to me about it— He asked me to whom I intended to give the vacant Clerkship— I said I proposed offering it to his Son— He said he would mention it to him— But he was thinking of the 1500 dollar Office, and I of the 1350 dollar one. When I wrote the Note offering the place to young Anderson, it first occurred to me to express explicitly which place I meant to offer him; but it seems his expectations had been of the other. I told his father I was sorry there had been any misunderstanding in the case, but Mr Bailey’s age and standing in Society, and respectability of character forbade me to put another person over his head— I called next at Mr Nourse the Register’s Office and conversed with him on the Affairs of the Indians— Thence I went to the President’s— Mr Calhoun was there, and the President introduced him to me— Mr Crawford came in— There was conversation upon various subjects. Mr Clay has already mounted his South American great Horse— Mr Robertson of Louisiana follows him non passibus acquis— Clay’s project is that in which John Randolph failed. To controul or overthrow the Executive, by swaying the House of Representatives. He intends to bring forward his motion to acknowledge the Government of Buenos-Ayres, and perhaps Chili, and Mr Crawford came with proposals from him to the Executive, professing a wish to harmonize with the Executive as to the manner of bringing it forward— Mr Calhoun pronounced himself most decisively against the measure; I had done the same before; and the President now, after some little hesitation did the same— I have no time to give the details— It was near three when I reached the Office— Furstenwerder, the Indians, Herrick and Hunt, of Ohio, and Blount of Tennessee occupied me, so that I had not a moment to read the Letters that came by the Mail— Dined with my wife at Commodore Decatur’s— Mr Gaillard President pro Tem: of the Senate, and the only remaining member of that body who was a member when I was there, Mr and Mrs Crawford, Judge Tait, Senator from North-Carolina, Mr Sanford, Senator from New-York, Mr H. St. George Tucker, Representative from Virginia, and Mr Schuyler a Representative from New-York, were there; and a Miss M’Knight— we came home between ten and eleven. The Thermometer has been three Nights successively at 18 and 19.

7. VI:30. The Coldness of the weather interrupts my occupation. I rise later, and am unable to write until the temperature of my room has been warmed by the fire— I had this morning the Mail of yesterday to read and then took up the Abbe de Pradt’s three last Months of South America and Brezil— Morning visit from Mr Purviance. Cardelli came, and we went with him to the Capitol, and looked over both the wings— I walked to the Navy-Yard and returned home to receive the Mail of the day. This employed me till dinner time— Mr. and Mrs Boyd, and Mrs Hellen, were here in the Evening—And the Abbé Correa the Portuguese-Minister— Thus the day slided imperceptibly away, and I had written scarcely a line: and among the Packets of yesterday’s and this day’s Mail there were several so voluminous that I have not even found time to read them through— I most especially regret the impossibility of detailing the most important occurrences and discussions, like that of yesterday.

8. VI:30. It was past twelve O’Clock when I was able to get out of my own house, and to call at the President’s. I was with him upwards of an hour, but so continually interrupted that it was impossible to transact any business. He objected to a great part of the draft that I had made of a Report on the Michigan Petition— I took it with me to alter it, or make a new draft; leaving out any allusion to the transactions of the late War, which might give Offence to Great Britain— At the Office, I had visits from the two Indians, Kusick and Longboard, who said Mr Caldwell had promised to draw up a memorial for them to Congress concerning their Church, and they asked to be introduced to the President— I promised to mention this request to the President to’morrow— Mr T. Cook, likewise called on me; and Captain Davidson, who brought the copies of his title deeds. I left the Office after five, and when I got home, found a Mr Motte of South Carolina, who brought us Letters from our Son George at Cambridge. He has a son there himself. Mrs Smith dined with us— I had an uninterrupted evening; but it was occupied altogether in reading—

9. V:30.Robert Munro, Printer of the Baltimore Patriot came this Morning to my house, to obtain the printing of the Laws of the present Session of Congress; it was taken the last Session from the American, to be given to the Patriot; and now the Editors of the American are excessively urgent to get it back, and alledge a promise to that effect. Munro is very anxious to retain the privilege, and saw the President about it, after which he came again to the Office— Mr Scott delegate from the Illinois Territory brought me a Letter from Mr John Pope— I called upon him, and Mr Nathl: Pope the delegate from the Missouri Territory at Davis’s Hotel, and also upon Mr Motte. At the President’s I met Mr Crowninshield; there are several calls from the House of Representatives for Papers and information— The President said we had had a battle with the Seminole Indians who were defeated and had fled into East Florida, and it was now a question whether they should be pursued there— At the Office Dr Cook, the Navy Chaplain came to ask me to permit him to receive 30 dollars of the 100 for which he gave me an order, to pay his debt to me— He has now 80 dollars due to him and offers to pay me 50 and give me a new order for the next 50 payable to him, being now in great want. I consented to this— The two Indians came, and I am to go with them to the President’s to-morrow at one O’Clock— Mr Austin Agent under the 4th. Article of the Treaty came he wished the Agency to be continued until the taking possession of the Islands in Passamoquoddy Bay; but he declines going as a special Messenger to England, with despatches on the subject. I am to speak again to the President concerning it— I left the Office at five. Mrs Boyd dined with us, and in the Evening my wife returned home with her.

10. VI:30.Mr Nathaniel Pope called this Morning at my house. I attended at the President’s with my Papers; and at One O’Clock went and presented to him the two Tuscarora Indians, Kusick and Longboard. They asked for a recommendation to take with them on their way; and to have their expenses here, and of traveling defrayed. The President directed that both their requests should be complied with; a special Passport was therefore made out for them at the Department of State, and I introduced them to the Secretary at War Mr Calhoun, at his Office, who promised to supply them to-morrow the means of defraying their expences— Dr Cook came again, and I consented that he should receive his pay due to him to the 6th. of this Month; paying me 50 dollars now and giving me a new order for the other fifty, upon his pay to accrue hereafter— Messrs.Otis, Mason, and Pierce of Boston, called at the Office, and Mr Barrell a Candidate for the Office of Consul at Malaga, excessively importunate. I received a Letter from him in the Evening. I left the Office after four O’Clock— My wife spent the Evening at a party at Mrs Weightman’s, and took an excuse for me— W. S. Smith came with a Member of Congress from New-York, Mr Hubbard, and afterwards Mr Forsyth of Georgia came, and sat an hour with me.

11. VI:30.G. G. Barrell came to my house this Morning to urge for the appointment of Consul at Malaga. I could not keep my temper with him, thinking that he pressed me beyond endurance— I spoke to him so harshly, that he immediately left me— He increased my exasperation, by apologizing for his want of knowledge of etiquette, as if he supposed some defect of that sort had provoked me— Mr N. Pope, the Delegate from the Illinois Territory came with D. Trimble and G. Robinson, Members of the House of Representatives from Kentucky, both of whom brought me Letters from John Pope— At the President’s I met Mr Crawford— The Tuscarora Indians came and took their Passport, to proceed on their Journey— I left my Office about four. Messrs. N. Pope, Trimble, Robinson, Scott and Austin, Boyd and his wife and Mrs Hellen, dined with us— Mr. Motte of South-Carolina came in after dinner— I lost of course my Evening’s occupation.

12. VI:30. On calling at the President’s this Morning, I met Mr Crowninshield there— The President was very anxious to have the papers called for by the House of Representatives, concerning Amelia Island and Galveston, sent this day, but that was impossible. He said the House were so impatient for them that if they were not sent this day there would be another call for them— There is one of the Papers, implicating the British Government, in such a manner that the President has thought proper to omit certain passages of the Letter, in the Communication to the house, but to give a copy of the whole to Mr Bagot, to be communicated to his Government— I gave him the copy this day— He expressed himself much gratified with the delicacy of this proceeding, and said he did not believe there was a word of truth in the Story told by the British Officer, Coll. M’Donald. I received a large Packet from Mr Sumter at Rio de Janeiro, with the Documents concerning the quarrel between Balk Poleff the Russian Ambassador, and the late Count da Barca— It took me almost the whole Evening to read them. My wife was very unwell and retired to bed immediately after dinner.

13. VI: I met Mr Calhoun this Morning at the President’s. We were engaged at the Office in collecting all the documents to be communicated to Congress; in answer to the call for papers relating to Amelia-Island, and Galvezton— Mr Gales and Judge Potter of North-Carolina called at the Office; and Mr Elliot a Clerk, under Dr Thornton of the Patent-Office; to give some explanations for the Doctor, in answer to the complaint of a person named Brewster. Gustavus M. Ware, who was one of the Seamen, belonging to the Ship Baltimore, and whom I had seen last year in London; came also to the Office, ostensibly to enquire if his wages had been recovered; but chiefly to tell me that he had changed his condition; married a Dutch wife, and made his Fortune. The weather was extraordinarily warm—Fahrenheit 62. My wife was confined the whole day to her bed— I received this Morning a new Reference from the House of Representatives, of a Petition with a budget of papers which it took me almost the whole Evening to read.

14. VI: Stormy Night and day. My wife was better, but not yet fully recovered. I attended Church at the Hall of the House of Representatives. The Sermon had commenced before I got there. The Preacher was a Presbyterian, who delivered his discourse without Notes, in a mystical, and fanciful style— but very fluent, and perfectly unsubstantial— I wished to have walked an hour or two after the service, but was compelled by the rain to return home. I received by the Mail, several packets from Mr Gallatin with the result of his and Mr Eustis’s Negotiation at the Hague, for a Treaty of Commerce with the Netherlands which has failed— I had visits from Genl. Harrison, and Mr Garnett, Members of Congress. In the Evening I wrote several short Letters.

15. VI:30. The Storm of Rain continued through the Night, and this Morning turned to Snow. Before Noon, the ground was covered. I rode to the President’s. Before Night it cleared off cold, and I walked from my Office home— At the President’s I met Mr Crowninshield. Mr Hyde De Neuville the French Minister, had requested an interview, and I appointed three O’Clock this day, at which time he came. He had a variety of subjects for discussion, and gave me two diplomatic Notes that he had ready prepared. He likewise asked me to appoint one day in a week when he might call on me, to talk upon Affairs— I named Tuesday’s at two O’Clock, and added that I should always be happy to receive him any other day in the week, when he might have any particular occasion to call. Spent the Evening in writing.

16. VI:30. At the President’s, and met Mr Crawford there. We had some discussion upon a demand yesterday made by the French Minister, for special privileges to French Commerce and Navigation in the Ports of Louisiana. I mentioned the grounds upon which I had objected to the demand, but Crawford thought there was no weight in my arguments. I received this morning a Note from Manuel Hermenegildo Aguirre the Agent from Buenos Ayres, demanding the recognition of that Government— His Letter to the President which has been so long mislaid was at last found this Morning; and many other papers the existance of which was unknown to me, are coming forth.
We had this day a diplomatic dinner. Mr Gaillard the President pro Tempore of the Senate— Mr Clay the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and Mrs Clay— Mr and Mrs Bagot, Mr Baker, the British Consul General and his brother James Baker; Mr Antrobus the British Secretary of Legation, and Mr Hughes, Mr Bagot’s private Secretary; Mr and Mrs Hyde de Neuville, and Mr Roth, the Secretary of the French Legation— Don Luis de Onis the Spanish Minister and his two daughters Madame de Heredia, and Miss de Onis, Mr Noëli, Secretary of the Spanish Legation, Mr Pizarro and Mr Stoughton, attached to it— Mr Correa de Serra, the Minister from Portugal, Mr Greuhm the Prussian Minister, and Mr Sasse, his Secretary; and Mr Ten Cate the Chargé d’Affaires from the Netherlands were invited— Mr Onis’s two daughters sent apologies, as being in mourning. Mr Hyde de Neuville was seized last Night with a violent rhumatism, and being confined to his bed sent an excuse. Mr Noëli sent also an excuse, being unwell; the rest of the company all came— The dinner was short and not well served. By nine O’Clock all the company were gone— Mr J. M. Baker was this Morning at my Office.

17. VI:30. My writing Cabinet was discomposed by the arrangements for yesterday’s dinner; and I lost both last Evening and this morning for writing.— And a single day’s intermission throws me into arrears excessively difficult to retrieve— General S. Smith of Baltimore, was here with his colleague Mr Culbreth to enquire about the mutineers of the Plattsburg, confined at Copenhagen— I told them the President had determined to send a public vessel to bring them to Boston as early in the Spring as the Navigation to Copenhagen would be open. I had a short visit this Morning at the President’s— At the Office we were hunting up the papers from South-America— Mr N. Pope the delegate from the Illinois territory spent the Evening with us.

18. VI:Mr Isham Talbott, one of the Senators from Kentucky, brought me a Letter from Mr John Pope. At the President’s I met Mr Calhoun— I had a Conference with the Spanish Minister Onis, concerning the Negotiation proposed between the two Governments— He is to send his proposals in writing— Mr Bagot called while Onis was with me and I did not see him. He came to say that Lord Selkirk, who is here, and goes away the day after to-morrow, wished to be presented to the President— Mr Brent went to the President’s and told him. The President desired Mr Brent to ask me to call at his house again. I went and he asked my advice how he should receive them— He concluded that I should inform Mr Bagot by a Note, that the President would receive him and Lord Selkirk to-morrow at One O’Clock. Mr Joseph Jones Monroe his brother and private Secretary should present them, and be present while they stayed— He would receive them not full dressed but in Stockings, and would invite them to sit while they stayed— I dined with Mr Daniel Brent at his brother Robert’s— Mr Daniel Carroll, with the Abbé Correa, Robert Walsh, and young Robert Brent constituted all the company, and we had quite a social party. My wife dined at her Sister Boyd’s— Their Mother Mrs. Boyd died at Mr Caldwell’s last Evening— I walked home from Mr Brent’s between 8 and 9.

19. VI:30. Omitted the usual call at the President’s this Morning, having no papers of importance to submit to him. And by a very unusual good fortune I had no interruption at the Office. I drafted a Letter to Mr Bagot containing a complaint against Lord Selkirk; and answered a Call from the House of Representatives, and one from a Committee of the House— I was further collecting Papers relating to South American Affairs— Attended this Evening a Ball in honour of the Duchess d’Angouleme’s Birth-day, at Mr Hyde de Neuville the French Minister’s. The company consisted of about two hundred persons, Members of Congress and Citizens of Washington— The foreign Ministers were all in full dress— Mr Bagot introduced Lord Selkirk to me— Mr Onis asked me for an answer to his Note about Amelia-Island— I told him that orders had been sent to Mr Erving, our Minister in Spain, to give suitable explanations to his Court— That it was for their benefit as much as our own. He said that M’Gregor had taken the Island with men, all enlisted at Charleston and Savannah— The Grand Jury of the Circuit Court at Philadelphia, refused to find a Bill against the British Officers arrested there— We came home immediately after supper, about Midnight.

20. VII:30. At the President’s this Morning I met his Son in Law, Mr George Hay, and as I was going to my Office I met Captain John Davidson with whom I am in Treaty for the purchase of a house and lots in F. Street. I sent him some days since a minute of papers necessary to complete the title. He told me this Morning that he believed he could furnish all the papers excepting one, which he was afraid would fail. His grantors have themselves only a bequest of the lots without words of inheritance— He said it was the first intimation he had of a defect in his title, but he did not know how it could be remedied— Mr Robertson of Louisiana, Mr Silsbee, and Mr M’Cormick the Clergyman, were successively at the Office, upon business of various kinds.
I dined with the Abbé Correa de Serra, who resides with Mr Robert Walsh— Mr Calhoun, and Mr Lowndes of South Carolina, Mr Rufus King— Mr Bagot and Lord Selkirk, with Mr Antrobus and Mr Hughes with Mrs Walsh, constituted the company. They all but myself went away immediately after dinner, but I sat in conversation with the Abbe and Walsh, till near eleven O’Clock— I received this day a Note from Mr. N. Pope, informing me that he is going immediately to New-York, and Boston, and asking Letters of introduction to both those places. The cold weather returned. Fahrenheit this Evening at 8.

21. VII: Fahrenheit at 7. and a strong North-west gale with a clear sky. I wrote several Letters of introduction, for Mr Pope; and I called upon him and left them with him at his lodgings. Mr Scott, Mr Robinson of Kentucky, and two or three other Gentlemen were with him— I took a walk of an hour and a half; over the Canal to the river. Below the Bridge— I found it frozen over. Thence I went over the fields, hard frozen to the Greenleaf’s point, and the Navy-Yard, returning home by the way of the Capitol. I found the benefit of my Russian Schoub and fur Cap— It would have been painful walking without them.

22. VII: Fahrenheit at 14. The day very cold. At the President’s I met Mr Crawford— The interruptions there are continual. Mr Samuel Bayard called upon me with Samuel Harrison Smith, and brought me a Letter from Mr M. B. Rornafu, Secretary of the American Bible Society at New-York, informing me that I have been elected a Vice-President of that Society. Mr Bayard comes here upon an application to Congress from the Society for the remission of duties. Mr Hyde de Neuville the French Minister came to the Office about two, and was with me till near five. The Conference was upon the subject of South America, and South American Privateers, the Commerce, Dignity and Policy of France and the like. It was important but I have not time to report even the slightest abstract of it— The Abbé Correa spent a couple of hours with us this Evening.

23. VII: Weather moderated. Fahrenheit at 22 this morning, and 28 this Evening. The day fine. At the President’s I met again Mr Crawford and made the statement of the Conference which I had yesterday with Hyde de Neuville. Mr Troup a Senator from Georgia came to enquire about an answer to the Resolution from the Senate relating to the Negotiation with England concerning Slaves carried away after the Peace— I told him what it was, and that a Report would immediately be made. Dr Phillips of Philadelphia, sometime a Surgeon’s Mate in the Navy, came with Letters from J. Gaillard and J. Sergeant,and solicited an appointment as Consul at Calcutta; but it is very doubtful whether the Government there will receive a Consul. Mr Aguirre the Agent of Buenos Ayres wrote a Note asking to see me, for which I appointed to-morrow at two. Dined with my wife at Mr Pleasonton’s. Mr Eppes a Senator from Virginia, and Mr G. W. Campbell from Tennessee, with their wives, General Lacock, Senator from Pennsylvania, Mr G. Hay, the President’s Son in Law, and Mr Joseph Jones Monroe his brother, were the company. It broke up at eight O’Clock, immediately after dinner, which is the custom here. I walked home.

24. VII: At the President’s this Morning I met Mr Crowninshield, who shewed me a plan very well drawn of the harbour of Boston— The President gave me for perusal, a statement from the Department of War, of a question between that Department and General Andrew Jackson— A Letter from the President to Jackson, of 5. October, and Jackson’s Answer of the 22d. The Department issued an order to a subordinate Engineer Officer within Jackson’s Division, directly to the Officer and not through Jackson as the Commander in Chief in the District. Jackson afterwards issued a general order throughout his district, forbidding his Officers to obey any order from the Department of War, not sent through him— The President’s Letter is very kind and conciliatory, but urges Jackson that he was wrong. The answer is moderate in language and acknowledges the conciliatory character of the President’s Letter, but adheres to the principle of Jackson’s order, and proposes a compromise of withdrawing his Order on condition that the Order from the Department of War, which occasioned his should be withdrawn first— Mr Aguirre came to see me, at the Office at two; and I had with him a Conference of nearly two hours— He gave me a copy of the Declaration
of Independence of Buenos Ayres, of 9. July 1816, and read to me in English a Paper, urging the acknowledgment of that Government by the United States— I asked him if it was in consequence of any new Instructions, he said no; but in consequence of what had passed in Congress on the subject— His instructions were to urge the recognition of Buenos Ayres, (and he had no commission as public agent from any other Government) as circumstances might occur to favour the demand; but he was expressly instructed not to urge it, at the hazard of embroiling the United States with any of the Powers of Europe— He told me there were three public Agents of Buenos-Ayres in Europe— One at London, one at Vienna, and the third had been under the guarantee of the British Minister at Madrid; but he believed was now gone to Paris— The proposals that he had made to Spain were that the King of Spain’s brother the Infant Don Carlos should be the Sovereign of Spanish South-America; but upon two Conditions. one the absolute Independence of South America, and the other that Don Carlos should go over alone, without any troops. Spain rejected these proposals, and would hear of nothing but unconditional submission— upon which the Declaration of Independence was made— I told him that all due weight and consideration should be given to his suggestions— I dined with my wife at Mr Crawford’s. Mr Gaillard, Mr and Mrs Clay, Mr and Mrs Calhoun, Mr MaconMr Troup, Mr Roberts, and a Miss Vail were the company— Clay came out with great violence against the course pursued by the Executive upon South American Affairs, and especially in relation to Amelia-Island. Clay is as rancorously benevolent as John Randolph— He has taken his stand of Opposition from the first day of the Session and his object is evidently to make grounds for it. There has been a strong expectation that he would hold this course, and he has not held the public or the Government in suspense concerning his intentions.

25. VII: Christmas day— My wife went with Mr D. Brent to the Catholic Church; and I went to the Hall of the House of Representatives, and heard a woman of the Society of Friends, Elizabeth H. Walker, pray, and discourse about three hours. The house was well filled— I had a morning visit from Mr Sanford a Senator from the State of New-York— Mr and Mrs Frye; his brother Frederick, and her Son, Robert Buchanan dined with us. After dinner we had a game of Loto. In the Evening, I was suddenly and severely seized with the rhumatism in my shoulder and left side. I went to bed in sharp pain, and threatened with a rhumatic fever.

26. VII: After a restless and painful night I rose this morning with a slight remnant of rhumatism in my shoulder, and with a severe Cold in the head. Received a Note from the President, asking me to call at his house at twelve O’Clock, to meet the other Heads of Departments, and consult upon the War, with a Southern tribe of Indians; the Seminoles. As I had other papers to lay before the President, I went to him at eleven, and reported to him the substance of the Conversation that I had with Mr Aguirre the day before yesterday— He told me that it was the practice of the Government to communicate in Confidence to all the heads of Departments, every important circumstance occurring in our foreign concerns, and also to the Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations; and he desired me to send to Mr Forsyth, and request him to call at my Office, and communicate with him very freely upon the posture of our foreign affairs— This had heretofore been the practice and had been found very useful to the Government. Mr Forsyth was friendly to the Administration, and any confidence might with perfect safety reposed in him— At twelve O’Clock, Messrs. Crawford, Calhoun and Crowninshield came in, and there was a deliberation upon the measures to be pursued, with the Seminole Indians, who have commenced actual hostilities; and cut off a detachment of fifty men going with a boat and provisions for a part of the troops under General Gaines— It was determined to send an order to Gaines to assemble all the disposable regular force within his reach, with the Addition of the Militia from the State of Georgia, and to reduce them by force, pursuing them into East-Florida, if they should retreat for refuge there, and that an order should be sent to General Jackson to repair immediately to the seat of War and take the command. The question recurred whether if possession has been taken of Amelia Island; after dispersing the unauthorized freebooters, and privateersmen who have taken it, our troops should retain possession of it, or abandon it to be occupied again by the Spanish Authorities from Florida. Mr Crawford was for giving it up; and the President evidently inclines also to that course— It was however determined to postpone that question— At the Office I had a call from General Roberts one of the Senators from Pennsylvania. My wife spent the Evening at Dr Thornton’s and took her Sister Mrs Hellen there. I sent an excuse, being unwell with my Cold, which threatens to settle upon my lungs; but I was closely occupied the whole Evening; writing an Answer to Mr Bagot upon the demand to deliver up mutineers at Boston, a Report to Mr Parris, Chairman of a Committee, and a Letter to T. Cadwalader.

27. VI:30. At the President’s this Morning, I met Mr Calhoun. I was much disappointed at receiving no news from Amelia Island which I had anxiously expected by the Southern Mail of this Morning. Mr Jeremiah Nelson, a Representative in Congress from Massachusetts came to the Office and made enquiries upon various subjects— Claims of indemnities from France, for captures prior to the year 1800. from Denmark in 1809-10. and 11. from England for vessels and Cargoes seized in British Ports at the commencement of the late War—and finally concerning the state of the Negotiation relating to the fisheries. Mr Edmund J. Lee, Mayor of Alexandria was likewise at the Office. My wife spent the Evening at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s the French Minister— I sent an excuse being still unwell with a severe Cold; for which I took a warm foot bath, and hot wine whey on going to bed— The weather has again become very moderate— Last Sunday is noticed in the Newspapers from the Northward as having been severely cold— At New-York Fahrenheit was at 3. and at Newark, New Jersey at 4.

28. VII: My cold continues so troublesome, that I omitted attending Church at the Capitol. My wife paid a number of visits. I walked to Georgetown, and returning met Edward Coles opposite the President’s House— He arrived last Evening from Richmond. Last Evening I made the draft of a Letter to Mr Eustis, and devoted the leisure of this day to reading the Outline of the Revolution in Spanish America; by a South-American— In the Evening I wrote a Letter to A. H. Everett— Part of the day was occupied in bringing up the arrears of my Journal.

29. V:30. I called this morning on Mr Jonathan Mason who has removed his lodgings from Bailey’s on the Capitol Hill, to Heronimex’s next door to my house. Stopped also at Pleasonton’s Office to enquire concerning the payment of 200 dollars to a man named Joseph Pavia, from the secret service fund, and for which a certificate from the President is necessary. Pleasonton explained the Circumstances to me— At the President’s; he told me that his house would be opened on New-Years day, at Noon to receive company— I enquired if a short time sooner should be appointed for the foreign Ministers; he at first objected, but afterwards said he would have a cabinet consultation upon it to-morrow between eleven and twelve. At the Office Mr Holker called upon me with Mr Nourse, and kept me an hour in detailing a claim that he has upon Daniel Parker, and concerning which instructions have been sent to Mr Gallatin— Received two letters from Onis, one a very long one to commence the negotiation, two Notes from Aguirre; pressing for the acknowledgment of Buenos Ayres, and voluminous despatches from Mr Gallatin; with a Supplement to the Dutch Negotiation. Received also Letters on important subjects from Mr Madison and from C. Collins— On returning home I received a Note from Mrs Swan, asking an interview; she is at Mrs Barlow’s at Kalorama— I answered appointing to-morrow Morning at ten, or the next day at 11 at my own house— In the Evening wrote to T. Sumter junr.— At Albany the 21st. Fahrenheit was 1. below 0.

30. VI: Rain. I rode to the President’s where I found Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun. They had agreed and the President determined to receive the foreign Ministers at half-past eleven, on New-Year’s day; half an hour before the general company, and I sent Notifications to the foreign Ministers to that effect— Also to Mr Ten Cate the Chargé d’Affaires of the Netherlands that I would then introduce him as Chargé d’Affaires of the Netherlands, and to Mr Greuhm the Prussian Minister, that he might then introduce Mr Sasse, his Secretary of Legation. At the Office, there came a Mr W. W. Morris of New-York, a son of Lewis Morris, one of the singers of the Declaration of Independence, and himself an Officer of our Army, in the War of Independence; he came to solicit office and brought Letters from the Governor of New-York, and Judge B. Livingston to the President. He also brought me a letter from H. J. Knox, renewing a solicitation for money— There was also a Mr Sidney Burrough, a solicitor for the appointment as agent at Cape Henry, Hayti— Mr Middleton, chairman of the Amelia Island Committee was also with me, and I gave him all the additional information that I possessed concerning it— I shewed him the secret Laws, those singular anomalies of our system, which have grown out of that error in our Constitution, which confers upon the Legislative Assemblies the power of declaring War; which in the theory of Government, according to Montesquieu and Rousseau
is strictly an Executive Act. But as we have made it Legislative, whenever secrecy is necessary for an operation of the Executive involving the Question of Peace and War, Congress must pass a secret Law to give the President the power— Now secrecy is contrary to one of the first principles of Legislation; but this absurdity flows unavoidably from that of having given to Congress instead of the Executive the power of declaring War. Of these secret Laws there are four, and one Resolution; and one of the Laws that of 25. June 1812 is so secret that this day it could not be found among the Rolls at the Department— Another consequence has also followed from this clumsy political machinery— The injunction of secrecy was removed on the 6th. of July 1812 from the Laws previously passed, by a vote of the House of Representatives, and yet the Laws have never been published— Mr Middleton said he would see me again, before he should make his Report, to the House. I was engaged all the Evening in writing an answer to C. Collins— The thermometer Fahrenheit’s was at 5 below 0 at Salem, and 5 above 0 at Baltimore.

31. VI:30.Mrs Swan came at eleven O’Clock this Morning according to appointment— E. Coles was here at the same time. She gave a hint that she had business with me, and Coles immediately withdrew— She came to solicit the interference of this Government to obtain the release of her husband James Swan, from the prison of la Force at Paris where he has been ten years confined— He was there upon a sentence obtained in the Courts of France after three trials— A very unjust sentence for they were debtors to Mr Swan for 150,000 dollars, instead of being his Creditors— All Mr Swan wanted was to get released and come to this Country for a fair trial. But he would never pay the money of the Sentence decreed against him there. A great deal of money had been sent to Mr Swan by her; but it had all been absorbed in the expences of the trials. Mr Hyde de Neuville had befriended Mr Swan very much, and thought if the Government of the U. S. would interpose, his release might be obtained. I promised to speak with Mr de Neuville upon the subject, and if any thing could be done for Mr Swan, very readily to do it— Madame Plantou came with a Print of her allegorical picture of the Peace of Ghent; for which she laid me under a contribution. It is a bombastic and foolish thing, but Madame Plantou gives herself out for a native of Philadelphia, and is a Painter. This is one of her works— There is an America, in a triumphal Car, and a Britannia, upon her knees, submitting to terms of Peace dictated by Minerva, and Hercules— Oh! the voracious maw, and the bloated visage of National vanity— If it were true that we had vanquished or humbled Britannia it would be base to exult over her, but when it is so notorious that the issue of our late War with her was at best a drawn game there is nothing but the most egregious National vanity that can turn it to a triumph— I received this morning Notes from Mr Bagot and Mr Hyde de Neuville, to ask if their Ladies could visit Mrs Monroe to-morrow. At the President’s where I met Mr Crowninshield, there was again a consultation; and my wife called one the Ladies and informed them that they would also be received at half past eleven to-morrow— At the Office I had another long Conference with the Agent from Buenos Ayres, Mr Aguirre—Urging still for the acknowledgment of his Government. He came to enquire whether it was of any importance that he should remain here, or whether he might go to Baltimore or Philadelphia where he could find useful business to do. I told him he must judge of that for himself. That his demand for the acknowledgment of his Government was under Consideration of the President; and that if he should go to Baltimore or Philadelphia, and any thing important should occur requiring his presence here, I could have immediate notice given to him— We had a short visit this Evening from the Abbe Correa the Portuguese Minister, and from Mr. and Mrs. Walsh.

Day. In its general arrangement the same as the last Month; but on the first Day of December the Session of Congress commenced, since which the business of my Office has been more pressing than before. On the other hand during five or six days of very cold weather I rose much later in the Morning and could scarcely write at all—and we have dined several times and spent evenings abroad which makes late hours, idle habits and waste of time— My indispensable business runs in arrear, and some times crowds me almost to distraction— I seldom reach my Office before one O’Clock, or leave it till five.

I close the year with humble Gratitude to God for his manifold Mercies to me and mine during its course. It has been the period of another great change in the condition of my life, upon which I once more implore the blessing of Providence, to my Country my family and myself. That I may know, and be enabled faithfully to discharge the duties of my Station; and that my heart and mind may be prepared for every dispensation of the divine wisdom and goodness.
